Identity.GuidelineTitle: 2008 Third Edition of the Guidelines for the Use of Antiretroviral Therapy in Malawi

KnowledgeComponents.Recommendation:
The first priority for CD4 count testingThe first priority for CD4 count testing is to identify patients who are eligible for ART HIV-positive pregnant women HIV statuspositive
Pregnancy statuspregnant
WHO clinical stage1 or 2
CD4-lymphocyte count testing should be ordered
HIV-infected children age categorychild
HIV statuspositive
CD4-lymphocyte count testing should be ordered
WHO clinical stage2
CD4-lymphocyte count testing should be ordered

The second priority for CD4 count testingThe second priority for CD4 count testing is to support the identification of patients on ART who might have treatment failure Whenever failure on ART is suspected Suspected ART failurepresent
CD4-lymphocyte count should be ordered
Base-line Base-line CD4 count test resultnot present
CD4-lymphocyte count should be ordered
CD4-lymphocyte counts should be measured at base-line

Regular follow-up CD4 countsThe third priority is to do regular follow-up CD4 counts on a) patients already on ART and b) persons who are HIV-positive but are not yet eligible for treatment. This should only be done once the first and second priorities have been adequately covered Follow-up every 12 months HIV statuspositive

Switching to second line - Patients with Suspected ART Drug FailureThe second line regimen is used when patients have failed the first line regimen. The final diagnosis of ART drug failure is made by a specialist or experienced clinician in dedicated clinics with access to viral load tests. Patients with Suspected ART Drug Failure need to be referred to these clinics. Suspected ART Drug Failure Classification - new WHO Clinical Stage 4 feature ART statuson ART
ART regimenfirst line
ART durationfor at least one year
ART adherence statusadhering to therapy
new WHO Clinical Stage 4 featurepresent
CD4 count< 200 cells/mm 3
CD4 counthas been repeated after one month and the result supports the earlier CD4 test
Patient has Suspected ART Drug Failure
Suspected ART Drug Failure Classification - CD4 count / CD4% ART statuson ART
ART regimenfirst line
ART durationfor at least one year
ART adherence statusadhering to therapy
CD4 count /CD4%has declined to pre-treatment values or less OR has declined to <50% of peak value on ART
CD4 count< 200 cells/mm 3
CD4 counthas been repeated after one month and the result supports the earlier CD4 test
Patient has Suspected ART Drug Failure
Patient presenting with Suspected ART Drug Failure Suspected ART Drug Failurepresent
refer patient to specialist or experienced clinician in dedicated clinics with access to viral load tests

patient is changed to:
stavudine plus lamivudine plus efavirenz (d4T + 3TC + EFV)
Stop triple therapy drug
Immediately start d4T and 3TC, one tablet twice a day, and continue for one week
Then stop d4T and 3TC, and wait until the rash or hepatitis has settled
Then start d4T and 3TC and EFV

ART IN SPECIAL SITUATIONS - Women: Childbearing Age & Pregnant Women CD4-lymphocyte count pregnancy statuspregnant
HIV statuspositive
should have a CD4-lymphocyte count performed to determine eligibility for ART even in the absence of symptoms
In the event of waiting lists for CD4-lymphocyte count, HIV-positive eligible pregnant women should be given priority
HIV-positive women should also be started on CPT

must take appropriate contraception to avoid getting pregnant

not be given nevirapine at the onset of labour

ART IN SPECIAL SITUATIONS - Patients with Liver Disease Patients with acute hepatitis ART eligibilityeligible
acute hepatitis (manifested by jaundice)present
patient should not be given d4T/3TC/NVP
Patients with established stable chronic liver disease stable chronic liver diseasepresent
ART eligibilityeligible
patient should be referred for specialist opinion about whether they can start ART

ART IN SPECIAL SITUATIONS - Patients with Renal Failure ART in case of renal failure ART statuson ART
renal failurepresent
Specialist advice is needed for the administration of ART
This treatment might be considered at central hospital level
Renal failure will not automatically exclude patients from treatment

ART IN SPECIAL SITUATIONS - HIV-Positive Adults and Children with TB ART eligible patients with tuberculosis HIV statuspositive
TB statuspositive
All patients with tuberculosis are potentially eligible for ART
Specialist opinion may dictate that some HIV-positive TB patients have ART deferred if the CD4 count is felt to be too high
initial phase of anti-TB treatment HIV statuspositive
ART statusnot on ART
anti-TB treatment phaseinitial
ART will not be given
In severely immuno-compromised patients in specialist centres, consideration may be given to starting ART within 2 weeks of initial phase anti-TB treatment
Prepare the patient with group counselling in initial phase
continuation phase of anti-TB treatment with rifampicin and isoniazid (RH) HIV statuspositive

anti-TB treatment phasecontinuation

patient is eligible for ART
Start at continuation phase with four-weeks continuation pack of d4T/3TC/NVP

CPT will be continued along with ART
patients should be given Â½ tablet of pyridoxine daily (12.5mg daily)
nevirapine-based regimens in association with rifampicin
Malawi will continue to use nevirapine-based regimens in association with rifampicin, and closely monitor the outcomes of patients

Management of patients already on ART who develop TB If there is any suspicion of TB ART statuson ART
suspicion of TBpresent
appropriate investigations (sputum smears, chest x-ray) must be undertaken
If TB develops when the patient is on ART ART statuson ART
TB test resultpositive
ART continues with d4T/3TC/NVP, and anti-TB treatment started in the usual way
If patients on first line ART develop drug-resistant TB ART statuson ART
ART regimenfirst line regimen
drug-resistant TBpresent
second line anti-TB treatment regimen can be given
If patients on second line ART (which contains protease inhibitors) develop TB ART statuson ART
ART regimensecond line regimen
TBpresent
second line ART regimen will have to be modified
Specialist opinion must be sought about what this modified second line ART should be
If patients on second line ART develop drug-resistant TB ART statuson ART
ART regimensecond line regimen
drug-resistant TBpresent
second line anti-TB treatment regimen can be given

Management of Kaposi â€™s sarcoma In patients with mild to moderate disease KS disease stagemild to moderate disease which does not limit function
HIV statuspositive
ART can be given alone
For others (severe) HIV statuspositive
KS disease stagesevere
six weekly doses of vincristine may be started either before or concurrently with ART

Management of Occupational and Accidental Exposure What to do after occupational exposure Exposure statusexposed
Use soap and water to rinse any wound or skin site in contact with infected blood or fluid
Rinse exposed mucous membranes thoroughly with water
Irrigate generously any open wound with sterile saline or disinfectant solution (2-5 min)
Eyes should be irrigated with clean water, saline or sterile eye irrigants.
Report to the clinician on duty as soon as possible
Treatment should be initiated within 1-2 hours of exposure, but if there are delays, PEP can still be started up to 72 hours after the exposure
Zidovudine 300 mg plus Lamivudine 150 mg are given twice a day for 30 days: the appropriate dose schedules are followed for children

Patient visits
Patients will be seen two weeks after starting ART, and then 4- weekly. After 6 months, if stable and adherent and if they have attended another formal group counselling session, review visits can be increased to once every two months and sometimes to once every three months
Patients will be seen two weeks after starting ART, and then 4- weekly. After 6 months, if stable and adherent and if they have attended another formal group counselling session, review visits can be increased to once every two months and sometimes to once every three months
